title: Testing
description: Requirements for product and environmental testing programs including microbiological testing, water quality testing, allergen testing, laboratory qualifications, and test result documentation

requirements.text: Is there a written risk-based, scientifically valid environmental monitoring program?
requirements.question: Is there a written risk-based, scientifically valid environmental monitoring program?
mandatoryStatements: A written environmental monitoring program must be implemented based on risk assessment and scientific principles
Program must define target organisms, sampling locations, frequencies, and corrective action procedures
Program design must address pathogen harborage sites and environmental contamination routes
requirements.verificationExpectations: Auditors will review the written environmental monitoring program to confirm it is risk-based with sampling focused on areas and surfaces that could harbor or transfer pathogens to products. Program should specify target organisms (Listeria, Salmonella, indicators), sampling locations in zones based on proximity to product, sampling frequencies, sample sizes, and analytical methods. Scientific rationale should support the program design.
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Operations should implement the environmental monitoring program consistently with sampling performed at specified frequencies and locations. Results should be trended to identify problematic areas with program adjustments made when trends indicate emerging issues or when facility changes create new risk areas.

requirements.text: Are there written risk-based corrective action procedures for when unacceptable environmental monitoring test results are received, that describe the steps to be taken, and assign responsibility for taking those steps?
requirements.question: Are there written risk-based corrective action procedures for when unacceptable environmental monitoring test results are received, that describe the steps to be taken, and assign responsibility for taking those steps?
mandatoryStatements: Written corrective action procedures must define response to unacceptable environmental monitoring results
Procedures must describe steps to be taken including immediate actions, investigations, and verification
Responsibility must be assigned for executing corrective actions and verifying effectiveness
requirements.verificationExpectations: Auditors will review corrective action procedures for environmental monitoring to confirm they are risk-based with escalating responses depending on organism detected and location found. Procedures should address immediate actions (cleaning, sanitizing, retesting), product holds when necessary, investigation to identify root cause, enhanced cleaning or structural modifications, verification testing, and documentation requirements. Responsibilities should be clearly assigned.
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Operations should implement corrective action procedures promptly when unacceptable results are received with documentation showing all steps were completed. Verification testing should confirm corrective actions were effective before resuming normal operations. Repeated positives should trigger enhanced investigations and more aggressive corrective measures.

requirements.text: Are there records of environmental microbiological test results and does testing meet the program requirements?
requirements.question: Are there records of environmental microbiological test results and does testing meet the program requirements?
mandatoryStatements: Complete records must be maintained for all environmental microbiological test results
Testing must be performed according to program requirements for locations, frequencies, and target organisms
Records must enable trend analysis and verification that the program is being followed
requirements.verificationExpectations: Auditors will review environmental monitoring records to confirm testing is performed according to program requirements including correct locations, frequencies, and target organisms. Records should document sample identification, location, date, organisms tested, results, and any corrective actions taken. Testing should be current with no unexplained gaps in the sampling schedule.
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Operations should maintain complete environmental monitoring records that are reviewed regularly to identify trends, verify program compliance, and detect emerging problems. Records should be analyzed to assess program effectiveness with adjustments made when results indicate inadequate sampling frequency, missing locations, or persistent contamination issues.

requirements.text: Is there a written program describing the operation's requirements for other microbiological or chemical testing not identified in 5.16.01?
requirements.question: Is there a written program describing the operation's requirements for other microbiological or chemical testing not identified in 5.16.01?
mandatoryStatements: A written program must describe all other microbiological and chemical testing requirements beyond environmental monitoring
Program must specify what is tested, frequencies, methods, acceptance criteria, and corrective action triggers
Testing program must address product testing, raw material testing, and other relevant quality and safety parameters
requirements.verificationExpectations: Auditors will review the testing program to confirm it describes microbiological and chemical testing requirements not covered by the environmental monitoring program including product testing, raw material testing, allergen testing, pesticide residue testing, heavy metals, or other parameters relevant to the operation. Program should specify sampling plans, analytical methods, acceptance criteria, and data review procedures.
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Operations should implement the testing program consistently with documentation showing required testing is performed at specified frequencies. Test results should be reviewed to verify acceptance criteria are met with investigations and corrective actions when out-of-specification results are obtained.

requirements.text: Are there written risk-based corrective action procedures for when unacceptable other microbiological or chemical test results are received, that describe the steps to be taken, and assign responsibility for taking those steps?
requirements.question: Are there written risk-based corrective action procedures for when unacceptable other microbiological or chemical test results are received, that describe the steps to be taken, and assign responsibility for taking those steps?
mandatoryStatements: Written corrective action procedures must address unacceptable microbiological or chemical test results
Procedures must be risk-based with steps proportionate to the food safety or quality significance of the failure
Responsibilities must be assigned for product holds, investigations, corrective actions, and verification
requirements.verificationExpectations: Auditors will review corrective action procedures for product, raw material, and other testing to confirm they describe risk-based responses to unacceptable results. Procedures should address product holds or recalls when necessary, root cause investigation, supplier notification for raw material issues, process adjustments, retesting to verify corrections, and documentation. Responsibility should be clearly assigned for each step.
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Operations should implement corrective action procedures promptly when unacceptable test results are received with documentation showing immediate product protection, thorough investigation, effective corrective actions, and verification of corrections. Trends in test failures should be analyzed to identify systemic issues requiring preventive actions.

requirements.text: Are there records of microbiological tests on water used in the facility (sampled from within the facility) and does the testing meet the program requirements?
requirements.question: Are there records of microbiological tests on water used in the facility (sampled from within the facility) and does the testing meet the program requirements?
mandatoryStatements: Microbiological testing records must be maintained for water used in the facility sampled from internal use points
Testing must meet program requirements for frequencies, locations, and target organisms
Water testing must verify potable water quality is maintained throughout the facility distribution system
requirements.verificationExpectations: Auditors will review water testing records to confirm microbiological testing is performed on water sampled from within the facility at representative use points. Testing should meet program requirements for frequency (typically monthly or more often), target organisms (total coliforms, E. coli, generic E. coli), and sampling locations. Records should show water meets potable water standards consistently.
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Operations should sample and test facility water according to the program with increased frequency during warmer months or when system modifications occur. Positive coliform results should trigger immediate retesting, investigation of contamination source, corrective actions including system sanitization, and verification testing before resuming normal water use.

requirements.text: Are there records of microbiological tests on ice used in the facility (either produced in-house or purchased) and does testing meet the program requirements?
requirements.question: Are there records of microbiological tests on ice used in the facility (either produced in-house or purchased) and does testing meet the program requirements?
mandatoryStatements: Microbiological testing records must be maintained for all ice used in the facility whether produced in-house or purchased
Testing must verify ice quality meets potable water standards and is free from pathogenic contamination
Testing frequency and parameters must align with program requirements based on ice use and risk
requirements.verificationExpectations: Auditors will review ice testing records to confirm microbiological testing is performed on ice used for product cooling, processing, or other food contact purposes. Testing should meet program requirements for frequency (typically monthly for in-house production, periodically for purchased ice), target organisms (total coliforms, E. coli, generic E. coli), and sampling protocols. Records should demonstrate ice meets water quality standards.
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Operations should test ice according to program requirements with in-house produced ice tested regularly and purchased ice tested to verify supplier quality. Ice makers and storage should be cleaned and sanitized on regular schedules with testing after cleaning to verify effectiveness. Contaminated ice should trigger immediate disposal, equipment cleaning, and investigation.

requirements.text: Are there records of tests performed on compressed air or other mechanically introduced gases that are used directly on food and food contact surfaces and does testing meet the program requirements?
requirements.question: Are there records of tests performed on compressed air or other mechanically introduced gases that are used directly on food and food contact surfaces and does testing meet the program requirements?
mandatoryStatements: Testing records must be maintained for compressed air and gases used directly on food or food contact surfaces
Testing must verify air quality is acceptable for food contact use including absence of oil, water, and microbial contamination
Testing frequency must meet program requirements based on risk and regulatory expectations
requirements.verificationExpectations: Auditors will review testing records for compressed air and gases used in direct food contact to confirm testing meets program requirements. Testing should address microbial contamination, oil content, water content, and particulates as appropriate for the application. Testing frequency should be sufficient to verify air treatment systems are functioning properly (typically annually or more often).
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Operations should test compressed air and gases according to program requirements with filter maintenance and dryer function verified regularly. Test failures should trigger investigation of air treatment system function with corrective actions to restore proper air quality before food contact use resumes.

requirements.text: Are there records of other tests (e.g., spent sprout irrigation water, product, raw ingredients, etc.) that are performed for any reason (e.g., customer requirements, best practice, regulatory requirements) and does testing meet program requirements?
requirements.question: Are there records of other tests (e.g., spent sprout irrigation water, product, raw ingredients, etc.) that are performed for any reason (e.g., customer requirements, best practice, regulatory requirements) and does testing meet program requirements?
mandatoryStatements: Records must be maintained for all testing performed whether driven by customer requirements, regulations, or best practices
Testing must be performed according to applicable program requirements including frequencies and methods
Documentation must demonstrate compliance with customer, regulatory, and internal testing commitments
requirements.verificationExpectations: Auditors will review records for other testing performed including product testing, raw ingredient testing, irrigation water for sprouts, or any other testing required by customers, regulations, or internal programs. Records should demonstrate testing is performed at required frequencies using appropriate methods with results documented. Testing should meet all applicable requirements from customers, regulations, or company programs.
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Operations should maintain testing schedules that capture all required testing from various sources (customer specs, regulations, company programs) with tracking to ensure testing is completed on time. Test results should be reviewed and communicated to stakeholders as required with corrective actions when specifications are not met.

requirements.text: Are there records of corrective actions taken after any unsuitable testing results that describe the steps taken, responsibility for taking those steps, and actions taken to ensure that the cause of contamination has been identified and corrected?
requirements.question: Are there records of corrective actions taken after any unsuitable testing results that describe the steps taken, responsibility for taking those steps, and actions taken to ensure that the cause of contamination has been identified and corrected?
mandatoryStatements: Corrective action records must document response to all unsuitable testing results
Records must describe immediate actions taken, root cause investigation, and corrective measures implemented
Documentation must demonstrate responsibility was assigned and effectiveness of corrections was verified
requirements.verificationExpectations: Auditors will review corrective action records to confirm unsuitable test results trigger documented investigations and corrective actions. Records should describe immediate product protection actions, investigation to identify contamination source or cause, corrective actions implemented to eliminate the cause, responsibility assignments, timeline of actions, and verification testing or other methods to confirm corrections were effective.
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Operations should investigate all unsuitable test results with documentation showing thorough root cause analysis and effective corrective actions. Verification should confirm the cause was identified and corrected with follow-up monitoring to ensure the problem does not recur. Trends should be analyzed to identify systemic issues requiring preventive actions.

requirements.text: Is there a documented training program with training records for the sampling personnel, including aseptic sampling collection techniques, sampling protocols and sample handling?
requirements.question: Is there a documented training program with training records for the sampling personnel, including aseptic sampling collection techniques, sampling protocols and sample handling?
mandatoryStatements: A documented training program must exist for personnel who collect samples for testing
Training must cover aseptic sampling techniques, sampling protocols, and proper sample handling
Training records must demonstrate sampling personnel are competent to collect representative, uncontaminated samples
requirements.verificationExpectations: Auditors will review the sampling training program and records to confirm personnel who collect samples are trained in aseptic techniques to avoid sample contamination, proper sampling protocols for each sample type, sample identification and labeling, chain of custody, temperature control during transport, and timely delivery to the laboratory. Training should include hands-on practice with competency verification.
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Operations should provide sampling training to all personnel who collect environmental, product, water, or other samples with documentation showing training completion and competency assessment. Sampling personnel should be monitored periodically to verify proper technique is maintained with retraining when deficiencies are observed or when protocols change.

requirements.text: Where food safety related testing is being done in-house, is there a laboratory quality assurance manual with protocols and validated testing methods, evidence of training on testing protocols and methods, and relevant supporting documentation?
requirements.question: Where food safety related testing is being done in-house, is there a laboratory quality assurance manual with protocols and validated testing methods, evidence of training on testing protocols and methods, and relevant supporting documentation?
mandatoryStatements: In-house laboratories must maintain a quality assurance manual with documented protocols and validated testing methods
Laboratory personnel must be trained on testing protocols and methods with training documented
Supporting documentation must demonstrate methods are validated and laboratory maintains quality controls
requirements.verificationExpectations: Auditors will review the laboratory quality assurance manual to confirm it includes validated testing methods, quality control procedures, equipment calibration protocols, proficiency testing participation, corrective action procedures, and documentation practices. Training records should show laboratory personnel are qualified and trained on methods they perform. Supporting documentation should include method validations, equipment calibration records, quality control charts, and proficiency testing results.
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Operations with in-house laboratories should maintain the QA manual as a current document that guides laboratory operations. Quality control samples should be analyzed with each batch, equipment should be calibrated on schedule, and proficiency testing should be performed regularly to verify laboratory competency. Method validations should be documented and reviewed when methods or matrices change.

capaInject: Implement immediate corrective actions when environmental monitoring detects pathogenic organisms including enhanced cleaning and retesting verification
Establish procedures for investigating root causes when microbiological test results exceed acceptable limits including environmental assessments
Develop action plans when water quality testing reveals coliforms or other indicators requiring system sanitization and source investigation
Create preventive measures for areas with persistent positive environmental monitoring results including equipment redesign or enhanced sanitation
Implement verification procedures to ensure testing laboratories maintain ISO 17025 accreditation and use validated testing methods
traceabilityInject: Maintain environmental monitoring program documentation including sampling locations, frequencies, target organisms, and scientifically validated rationale
Keep complete records of environmental microbiological test results with sampling dates, locations, organisms tested, and result interpretation
Retain corrective action records for unacceptable test results including investigation findings, remediation actions, and verification testing
Document water quality testing results including microbiological and chemical parameters, sampling points, and frequency compliance
Archive laboratory qualifications including ISO 17025 accreditation certificates, method validation reports, and proficiency testing results
micro_inject: Inadequate environmental monitoring fails to detect Listeria monocytogenes harborage sites allowing persistent contamination of ready-to-eat products
Water sources contaminated with E. coli or coliforms introduce pathogenic bacteria directly into product wash and cooling systems
Insufficient product testing frequency fails to identify pathogen contamination events including Salmonella outbreaks before distribution
Poor laboratory practices including contaminated media or improper sterile technique generate false negative results masking pathogen presence
Failure to test for indicator organisms misses early warning signs of sanitation failures that precede pathogenic contamination events
